lines.text: It sounds like a boy Garry's age needs a man around the house.

Well, it depends on the man. I had a man around. He used to wake me up every morning by flicking lit cigarettes at my head. He'd say, "Hey, asshole, get up and make me breakfast." You know, Mrs. Buckman, you need a license to buy a dog, or drive a car. Hell, you need a license to catch a fish! But they'll let any butt-reaming asshole be a father.
He said that he loved me.
Men say that. They all say that. Then they cum.

[door slams as Tod leaves after having a fight with Julie]
If he thinks I'm having his baby now, he's crazy!

[shocked]
Baby?
Your daughter's having a baby?

[even more shocked]
A baby?
You're going to be a grandma?

[laughs incredulously]
No, no, no, no. I'm too young to be a grandmother. Grandmothers are old. They bake, and they sew, and they tell you stories about the Depression.
[shouts]
I was at Woodstock, for Christ's sake! I peed in a field! I hung on to The Who's helicopter as it flew away!
[gestures wildly]
I was at Woodstock.

[shouts]
Oh yeah? I thought you looked familiar!
Can I speak frankly, no holds barred?
[Helen nods]
That is one messed up little dude. We can talk straight?
[Helen nods again]
Um, a few months ago, Garry got his first... boner. You know what that is?
If memory serves.
Aw, great! Anyway, since then, he's been... uh... slappin' the salami. No offense.
No.

Apparently, he's goin' for a world record. Anyway, he was afraid there was something wrong with him, you know? Like he was a pervert or something. I told him that's what little dudes do - we've all done it. It made him happy.
Garry was happy?
He even smiled! I never even knew he had teeth!
I happen to LIKE the roller coaster, okay? As far as I'm concerned, your grandmother is brilliant.
Yeah, if she's so brilliant, why is she sitting in our NEIGHBOR'S CAR?
What's the matter, honey? You don't feel so good?
Yeah.
You feel like you wanna throw up?
Okay.
[vomits all over Gil, and starts crying]
Oh Taylor, baby... Gil, why are you standing there?
Waiting for her head to spin around.
Someone's gone to the roof of the bell tower with a rifle!
It's Kevin Buckman! His father totally screwed him up!
What's he yelling?
YOU MADE ME PLAY SECOND BASE!

[Yelling through a megaphone]
Son, I'm sorry. I did all the best I could.
[Kevin shoots the megaphone from his hands]
Nice shot, son! It's important to be supportive. Come on, let's sing one of the old tunes. "When you're sliding into home and your pants are full of foam, diarrhea..."

[after breaking the lock on Gary's bedroom door and searching it, Helen finds some sex tapes and plays one - graphic sex sounds from the television as Susan and Grandma enter the room]
Helen? Oh, the door was unlocked.
[sees the sex action on the television]
What channel is this?
No Gran, this is a tape.

[to Susan]
She needs a man... Now!
Gran, this isn't mine. I don't watch this!

[to Susan again as they are leaving the room and speaking of the sex action on the television]
One of those men reminded me of your Grandpa. God bless him!
[after finding her 15-year-old son's bag full of porno tapes]
l assume you're watching these because you're curious about sex... you know. Or filmmaking.
I wouldn't live with you if the world were flooded with piss and you lived in a tree!
Do you really have to go?
My whole life is "have to."
[Gil has been complaining about his complicated life; Grandma wanders into the room]
You know, when I was nineteen, Grandpa took me on a roller coaster.
Oh?
Up, down, up, down. Oh, what a ride!
What a great story.

I always wanted to go again. You know, it was just so interesting to me that a ride could make me so frightened, so scared, so sick, so excited, and so thrilled all together! Some didn't like it. They went on the merry-go-round. That just goes around. Nothing. I like the roller coaster. You get more out of it.
Keep Patty away from Larry - suck the intelligence right out of her.
[after inhaling helium]
When I was a girl, Grover Cleveland was president. Hehe!
[Tod is struggling with Julie]
Julie, you belong with me!

[hitting him]
Let go of her!
You're my wife!
I said-!
[stops]
His what?
His wife. We got married a few days ago.

[hitting her]
Are you out of your *mind*? Are you out of your *mind*?

[watching Larry get thrown from a moving car and rolling up next to his feet]
What was that?

[Larry stands up and brushes himself off]
Oh, some - friends of mine were just dropping me off.
Friends? Friends slow down, they even stop!
[Larry walks away chuckling]
[whimpers as she flips through the stack of sex photos of Julie and Tod]
[Julie enters the room and Helen holds up a picture]
I... I... I think this this one is my favorite.
It was just for fun, Mom.
Well, I'm glad to know it's not a job. That's that Tod, isn't it? There's one with his face.
[as she looks closer at the photos]
Is that what bothers you? That I did those things? Or that I did those things with Tod?
Gee whiz, Julie, so many things bother me about this, I don't know where to separate them.
[holds up a different photo]
Oh! Whoo! Here's something for my wallet!
Tod is very important to me.
And we've got the photos to prove it!
[as she holds up the sex photos again]
Mom...

[looking again at the photos]
This is your room. You did these things right here? In my house?
Well, I thought someone in this house ought to be having sex. I mean with something that doesn't require batteries.
Cool is adorable. Adorable! Why didn't you write us when you had a son?

I didn't know myself until a couple of months ago. You see, a few years ago, I was living in Vegas with this girl. Showgirl. She was in that show 'Elvis On Ice'. Anyhow, we drifted apart, as people do in these complicated times, and then a couple of months ago, she shows up with Cool and tells me "You watch him. I shot someone. I have to leave the country."... That's a parent?
We'll throw away the TV. We'll perform Shakespeare in front of him.
Women have choices, and men have responsibilities.

[on parenting]
It's like your Aunt Edna's ass. It goes on forever and it's just as frightening.
What is it with all the women in this family, that makes all the men in this family wanna leave?
Who's that?
It's my kid brother, Larry, your uncle. Don't give him any money.
I won't.
You don't talk like a kid.
Yeah, well I'm not really a kid.
You're not a duck.
This is a memory of when I was a kid. I'm 35 now. I have kids of my own. You don't even really exist. You're an amalgam.
A what?
A combination of several ushers my dad left me with over the years. I combined them into one memory.
Why?
This was a great symbolic moment of my life. My father dumping me with you... it's why I swore things would be different with my kids. It's my dream. Strong, happy, confident kids.
That's great, that's great. You know, you - you got a lovely family, and I'm a god-damn amalgam!
I can't do this! This is too intense!
This is marriage!
I swear, Julie, if you walk out that door, don't you dare come back!
Don't worry about it!
[Garry enters]
Hey Garry.
Hi.
I'm moving out.
Bye.
[walks out of the room]
See? Now you've upset your brother!

[upon finding Julie at her own house with her mother]
Julie, you're here!
What does that make you, Sherlock Holmes? I live here!
[after his wife just told him she's pregnant with their 4th child]
Well, great! Let's see how I can screw the fourth one up! Hey, let's have five. Let's have six. Let's have a dozen and pretend they're donuts!
Gil, you have a good memory. Uh, was it yours or Helen's or Susan's wedding I got drunk at?
It was all three, Dad. Congratulations.
Well, which one did I punch the band leader?
That was mine. We have photos. I'm having them blown up for the commitment hearings.
[Susan laughs]

[mimics Susan laughing]
Well, you think he's funny. Well, when he was a kid, he wasn't as funny. Stayed in his room all day. Boy, you were a moody little son of a bitch.

[sarcastically]
Gee, I wonder why.
They call me Cowboy Gil, as in guil-ty. I saw Cowboy Dan. I didn't like the look on his face. It was like this...
[smiles goofily]

... so I killed him. I blew a hole in him this big. Actually it was about this big. You know, when I think about it, that hole was about THIS BIG! And his guts were spilled out all over the floor. As I was walkin' away, I slip around on his guts. A couple of other people came by and started slippin' on his guts too. After I blow a hole in somebody and slip around on their guts... afterwards, I always like to make balloon animals. That's mighty courteous of you. Here we go!
[holds up jumbled of twisted balloons]
Your lower intestines.

[Frank has asked Gil for advice about Larry]
And you want my advice? Why me? Why now?
Because I know you think I was a shitty father.
[Gil is silent]
Thank you for not arguing. And I know you're a good father.
[after Gil and Karen get into an accident when she tries to "relax" him]
So, how did this happen?

[gives Karen a look]
Show him, honey.

[after power failure]
Your mouth used up all the power.
Did he say "Cool"?
Cool.

[after inspecting Susan's diaphragm and finding a hole]
Well?
Why are you pouring water through my diaphragm?
To check. To see if it's OK. You didn't know I did that, did you?
No.
Obviously not or you wouldn't have tried this.
Are you accusing me of making that hole?
No, a woodpecker came in here, went into the bathroom, opened the drawer with his little wing and pecked a couple of holes in your diaphragm!
[In the car after the baseball game, Kevin is singing "The Diarrhea Song" while Taylor laughs]

When you're sliding into first and you're feeling something burst, diarrhea, diarrhea. When you're sliding into third and you feel a juicy turd, diarrhea, diarrhea. When you're sliding into home and your pants are full of foam, diarrhea, diarrhea. When you're driving in your Chevy and your pants are feeling heavy, diarrhea, diarrhea.
Kevin, honey, where did you learn that song?
Last summer at camp, Mom.
Ah, that was money well spent.
When you're sliding into first and you're feeling something burst, diarrhea, diarrhea.

[Gil and Larry are reuniting]
How long has it been? Three years?
Something like that.
You stopped wearing your turban!

[laughs]
Yeah!

Open this door! Goddamnit! I was just like a little respect! Not a lot, just a little! Do you know why I'm having sex with machinery? Because your father went to have a party and I stayed to raise two kids, and I HAVE NO LIFE!
He likes to butt things... with his head.
How proud you must be.
[Gil sees Justin wearing nothing but a gunbelt]
That's what you're wearing to bed? You'll catch a cold!
[Justin puts on a cowboy hat]
Perfect!
[Karen enters]
Karen, how about after the kids are asleep... (referring to Justin.) I wear this outfit?

Thank you. When I was 9 years old, I had kind of a rough time. A lot of people thought I was pretty mixed up. But there was one person who got me through it. He did everything right. And thanks to him today, well I'm the happiest, most confident and most well-adjusted person in this world. Dad, I love you. You're the greatest!

[approaching Grandma]
Is that Grandma?
Yeah, she's still alive.

[Larry and Grandma laugh and embrace]
Jeez Grandma, you got short.
I'm shrinking!

[briefly chuckles]
Bummer!

[as her husband surprises her by serenading her in the middle of her lesson]
Nathan, we're trying so hard to keep these kids off drugs.
I can't believe I trusted him...
Well, what did you expect from a kid like that?
Oh, Mom, back off. The last guy you dated stole our furniture.

[interrupts foreplay to take out a picture camera]
Now we can record our love.
He's ruining the play! He's ruining the whole play!
They're bad dudes. That's why they call the game "Bad Dudes."
Hey, Gil, our boys finally gonna win one game?
Way to be supportive, Lou.
[about Tod and Julie's marriage]
I give them six months. Three, if she cooks.

[lights went out unexpectedly and have just been turned on. Gil thinks he has a flashlight but is holding a vibrator]
What's this?
[switches vibrator on]
[lights come up, Gil laughs and leaves the room]
Mommy, what was that?
That was... an electric ear cleaner.
It was kind of big.
It sure was!
Tod?
Yeah?
Do you want me to make you breakfast?
No thanks, Julie will.
Great.
[then adds under her breath]
I'll get the fire extinguisher.
You know, when you were two years old, we thought you had polio. Did you know that?
Yeah, Mom said... something about it a couple of years ago.
Yeah, well, for a week we didn't know. I hated you for that.
[Gil looks surprised and hurt]
I did. I hated having to care, having to go through the pain, the hurt, the suffering. It's not for me.
Hi. Where's my wife?
She's still at school. She's got cheerleading practice.
Bitchin'.

[seeing Taylor get pushed around in a school play]
They're hurting my sister!
He's going! Get him!
Hang on, Taylor! Taylor, I'm gonna save you.
Patty, why don't you play with Justin?
I don't understand what he's doing.
Well, he's... spinning.
What for?
Uh... no reason, just for fun.
It doesn't look like fun.
It isn't.

[gives Nathan a funny look]
You tried it?
What are you so upset about?
Nathan, she's weird. She's a weird child. I think a few days a week of preschool could be very helpful.
This is not the right age for Patty to be socially activated. We went through this.
She's not a bomb, she's a little kid who has no ability to relate to other little kids.

[points at Justin]
You want her to relate to him?
[Justin currently has his head stuck in the back of a sun lounger]
Help, help, help.

You see, when I met him, I was a little wild, I was a little out of control and he kind of... took me in hand. I liked that. He's very... commanding. He got me into teaching, he got my shit together. Boy, he really turned on.

[incredulous]
Really?
[changes her tone of voice]
I-I mean, uh, of course. Really?
Oh, Nathan and I used to be hot. I know he doesn't look it but, I mean, we were like rabbits. I used to give him... you know... oral, you know... on the highway.
What?
You know, he was always trying to get a research grant.
And you thought that would help?
No. But, I mean, he kept getting turned down and he'd get real, real tense. So, if I saw him getting, you know, really tense, I'd just... lean over while he was driving and, uh...

[reading a book]
The Penal Colony, by Franz Kafka.
Hey, Nathan, Patty a doctor yet?
Mock if you will.
All right.
Our children are more capable of retaining and absorbing information than we are and yet we insist on treating them like adorable little morons.
What are you saying, Patty can learn things I can't learn?

[lays out four cards with lots of red dots stuck on them]
Patty, which one of these is the square root of 8,649?

[looks at the cards for a few seconds then points at one]
93.
[Nathan picks up the card, checks the answer on the back then shows it to Gil. Patty is correct. Gil pulls an expression of disbelief and thumps his head with his palm]
They're like sponges, Gil, just waiting to absorb.

[picks up one of the cards]
I want this.
You see? Take my advice, forget about Kevin and Taylor, it's too late. Work on Justin.
Actually, Justin is quite bright. In his preschool class, he was the only...
[Justin picks one of the red dot stickers off the card and puts it in his mouth]
Slow down, Justin. I'll get you some dip.
You see, Grandma, Patty studies Eastern philosophy. Our future leaders are going to have to be much more in tune with the Oriental mind.
[Grandma looks confused and shakes her head]

Justin's going to go full time next year, so everybody's asking when I'm going to go back to work. Like I'm supposed to. And I'm thinking about it, I mean, I used to like work, it was OK, but... you know, I think I'm better at this, I mean, I think I'm sort of good at it, so... But then people make me feel embarrassed, like I don't have goals or something. Like I sit around here eating bonbons all day, right? Oh, I don't know.
Well, what does Gil say?
He says I should do whatever I want. I could have killed him for that.
